Roper Technologies (ROP) came out with quarterly earnings of $5.21 per share, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $5.14 per share. This compares to earnings of $4.81 per share a year ago. These figures are adjusted for non-recurring items.

This quarterly report represents an earnings surprise of +1.44%. A quarter ago, it was expected that this industrial equipment maker would post earnings of $5.11 per share when it actually produced earnings of $5.14, delivering a surprise of +0.59%.

news.headline: Roper shares dip as weak full-year outlook overshadows Q4 beat
news.article_text:
Investing.com -- Roper Technologies delivered a modest earnings beat in the fourth quarter, but the company’s full-year outlook fell short of market expectations.

Roper shares dipped more than 3% in premarket trading by 07:11 ET.

The company reported Q4 earnings per share of $5.21, topping the consensus estimate of $5.14. Quarterly revenue jumped 10% year-over-year to $2.06 billion, compared with analysts’ forecast of $2.08 billion.

On a per-share basis, the Sarasota, Florida-based company said it had profit of $3.97. Earnings, adjusted for one-time gains and costs, came to $5.21 per share.

news.headline: Is Shopify’s (SHOP) Agentic Commerce Pivot Rewiring Its Competitive Moat Or Just Its Partnerships?
news.article_text:
In recent weeks, Shopify has cut jobs in its partnerships division and overhauled how it works with third-party developers, agencies, and AI platforms, while continuing to report strong revenue growth and improving profitability.

An important twist is Shopify’s push into “agentic commerce,” including integrations that let merchants sell directly through AI assistants like ChatGPT, Gemini, and Copilot, potentially reshaping how shoppers discover and buy products online.

We’ll now examine how th

news.headline: Prediction: These 2 Growth Stocks Will Beat the Market Through 2031
news.article_text:
They are both great long-term holdings.

One industry that is almost certain to expand over the next five years is e-commerce. That's because, despite appearances, online retail hasn't killed the traditional shopping experience yet, not even close. For instance, in the U.S., e-commerce sales made up 16% of total retail sales in the third quarter.
